description: From New Latin tēctiformis (“roof-shaped”), from tēctum (“roof”) + fōrma.

adjectives.description: tectiform (comparative more tectiform, superlative most tectiform)

entries.meaning: (biology, anthropology) Roof-shaped; sloping downwards on two sides from a raised central ridge.
(anthropology) A type of cave painting or engraving, having in its simplest form the shape of an upward-pointing wedge or arrow, thought to represent the roof of a tent or rudimentary building.
examples: The tectiforms reproduce in a remarkable manner the simple shelters, tents, and huts in use today among primitive and nomadic races in various parts of the world.
